title: How to Keep Your Closet Tidy

steps.headline: Set aside part or even all of your day to clear your closet.
steps.description: Depending on how big or cluttered your closet is, assess how long you think it will realistically take to complete the task. Mark it on your planner or calendar so you don’t forget about it. It is better to plan for too much time than not enough.

steps.headline: Take absolutely everything out of your closet and put it on your bed.
steps.description: That way, you have to finish the task before you go to bed. If you have any clothes in storage, take them out of their boxes and put them on your bed too. This also includes any jewelry!

steps.headline: Deep clean your closet.
steps.description: We don’t often realize how much dust and dirt can be inside our closet even though it is mostly closed. Use a disinfectant spray with some paper towels, a damp cloth, or even a duster to make all surfaces spotless. Finish with some air freshener and let your closet air out for a bit.

steps.headline: Sort your closet contents into four piles.
steps.description: Have one pile called “I love this!,” another called “Maybe I’ll keep this,” another labeled “Donate,” and finally a pile called “trash.” Work through the pile on your bed until it is all clear and you can sleep tonight! Feel free to get a drink of water and a congratulatory snack. The key with this step is to not think too much about each item. Hold the item up and go with your gut reaction. This will thin out your closet much quicker.

steps.headline: Get rid of the “Donate” and “Trash” piles.
steps.description: Bag up the clothes you wish to donate and put them aside. Also bag up the clothes to be trashed, or consider repurposing them. For example, you can turn an old sock into a puppet craft for any young children in your life.

steps.headline: Sort through your remaining piles more thoroughly.
steps.description: Ask yourself the question, “Would I buy this if I saw it in stores?,” or “Do I see myself wearing this three months from now?” If the answer is “No” to these questions, throw these clothes into your bags for donation (unless it's an expensive or sentimental item). Congratulations! You now only have clothes you need and love!

steps.headline: Organize your remaining clothes by season.
steps.description: Make a pile of clothes that you would only wear for the current season. Box up any off-season clothes and put them in storage elsewhere for smaller closets, or put them on the top shelf so they will be out of sight. Make sure that you store your clothes in airtight plastic containers, because cardboard boxes can harbor dust and bugs.

steps.headline: Sort your clothes by occasion.
steps.description: Now that you are down to your favorite seasonal clothes, separate them into piles based on the occasion. For example, you don’t want to mix your party dresses with your workout clothes. This will enable you to find the right outfit quickly and efficiently.

steps.headline: Put everything back in your closet based on your personal preferences.
steps.description: Pick certain zones of your closet to house certain types of clothing. For example, if you like to base your outfit choice on the top you pick, put all of your tops on coat hangers in the most accessible part of your closet. If shoes are usually last, organize them on the floor somewhat out of the way. You can even sort your closet zones out by color. Picking your outfit can be even more efficient if you choose your outfit based on the color you want. Start with grouping your whites and work your way down to darker colors. Turn your closet into an organized rainbow! EXPERT TIP								Christel Ferguson			Professional Organizer				Hang your clothes on thin hangers instead of wooden ones. Wooden hangers take up a lot of space, and you can fit more clothes in your closet with thin ones.

steps.headline: Keep your accessories separate.
steps.description: Don’t just throw your bags and shoes into the corner! Invest in a jewelry holder you can display in your room, designate a section to hang your bags, or put a coat hanger on the wall to hang hats and bulky coats. Mixing any kind of accessory will slowly turn your closet back into the black hole it once was.

steps.headline: Invest in some velvet coat hangers.
steps.description: Clothes can slip off of wood or plastic hangers, while velvet hangers create enough friction that your clothes will stick on the hanger no problem! Plus, having uniform hangers adds an extra sense organization to your closet.

steps.headline: Store shoes on your door.
steps.description: Many stores sell pouches to store shoes that you can hang right over your closet door. This will free up any shelf space your shoes use, and keep them organized and tidy. If you are allowed, you can even hang multiple rails on your door to store high heels. In the case of tall boots, you can store these on hanger meant for slacks. Just clip a pair on each slack clip, and hang them up. This will also prevent them from flopping over and losing shape!

steps.headline: Use hanging shoe holders to store sweaters.
steps.description: Not all clothes are meant to be hung up, as knits and bulky sweaters can be stretched out of shape. Instead, buy a shoe organizer that you can hang up on your closet rod. You can roll up your sweaters and store them in the little cubby holes of the shoe organizer.

steps.headline: Use magazine holders for clutches and paper towel holders for belts.
steps.description: Take a trip to your office store and find some cheap, stylish magazine holders. Store any thin clutches in the holders just like you would a regular magazine. This will keep all of your clutches visible and ready to go. Likewise, find some cheap stand-alone paper towel holders and pile your rolled-up belts on the pole for a unique and creative storage solution.

steps.headline: Separate your top shelf with dividers.
steps.description: If you tend to let your top shelf be an area to simply toss anything and everything up there, invest in some shelf dividers. This will prevent any piles from falling over, and forces you to organize everything into categories.
